instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
the laptop was liquid damaged but I can't find any liquid on the board. The board was still working then customer changed the screen because liquid got into the screen then a few days later the touch bar has stopped working then the customer reboot the laptop and has stopped powering on.

fan spin, no light on USB mouse and the cpu is little warm.


PP20v -19.9v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13v
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.2v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.0v
PPVCCPRIMCORE_SUS_PCH - 1v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 1.2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> - 1,2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3v



<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0v

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 7 ohms


RIP CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: Check resistance between PPBUS and <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>. Is the CPU getting warm at all?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 39541"]Check resistance between PPBUS and <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>. Is the CPU getting warm at all?[/QUOTE]

yes cpu getting little warm.



you reckon <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> has killed the CPU?

the resistance between PPBUS and <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 1.0 M ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: It is definitely possible it died. PPBUS not being shorted to VCore is a good sign tho. If you plug in a USB mouse through an OEM USBC-USBA dongle, does it light up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: no, i wrote everything on the 1st post.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: Yeah that doesn't sound good at all

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: should i replace <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> to see if that will fix it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 0v"
So RAM is not powered up...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: sorry, <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> is there. my mistake. i'll try ultrasonic.
